ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was a lovely immersion into Nietzsche's texts. I learned to adopt a different philosophical framework and analyze experiences through it. Very useful for connecting Classical and Modern philosphy.
I learned a lot about Nietzsche's thought and about the possibilities that arise when the Principle of Sufficient Reason is given up. Additionally, this course helped improve my close-reading skills.
A thorough understanding of the core text, as well as Nietzschean philosophy more generally and an improved ability to evaluate images and characters in a philosophical context.
The course offered a deep understanding via close reading of Nietzsches Zarathustra, as well as taught literary analysis skills.
Interpretation of continental philosophy
Critical reading of one of philosphy's most complicated texts.
The message of this spoke zarathustra
It was wonderful to get to think through Nietzsche's fascinating text in this course, working through both the philosopher's specific insights and his general style of thinking.

Deep understanding of Thus Spoke Zarathustra, its context, and the purpose and style of its content
Ability to appreciate the German intricacies of the text, and recognize the pros and cons of translations
The movement of themes and images through the text as both symbols and examples of Zarathustra's life
Learned how to approach Nietzsche, how to develop a thought, and question and take risks.
Learnt a great deal about Nietzsche's philosophy in a systematic way. Learnt lots of interesting ways to read a text: philologically, through an image, and so on.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Excellent, one of a kind course  potentially could have benefited from a smaller seminar size and more small group discussions.

The course was overall very good. The discussions were engaging, the closely-read passages well-selected, and the professor was very responsive. In person I'm sure the course would have been even better, but I have no other improvements to suggest.
The strengths were the discussions. Not a weakness, per se, but sitting for three hours straight on zoom was a bit rough. Perhaps splitting the class into two 1.15 hour classes might help with this.
I think the high number of students may have limited the quality.
Big strength is format and material, 3 hour seminars are tough though especially voer zoom.
Very open discussions among students

Strengths: 
spends enough time on each section of the book for meaningful differences to arise in interpretation, encourages student interpretation, synthesizes core themes and concepts into a digestible format and structure, engaging writing assignments that exercise different linguistic and philosophic skills with writing styles; clearest writing prompts I've ever encountered that made the purpose, limits, and freedoms of an assignment available to every student (I really appreciated this)
Weaknesses: 
would've liked more instruction and less discussion
One of the best courses I have taken at Yale. Professor North facilitated discussions in a way that targeted students' interests but always had an overarching point.

This class was brilliant! There was always good discussion in class, and Prof. North guided us towards unexpected and often controversial directions. By reading the notoriously opaque Zarathustra, he showed us how to make dense texts clear and illuminating -- I dare say that I think differently now.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The quick-writes in class were useful ways to spark discussion even virtually, but the breakout rooms were hit-or-miss, as is the case with any course.
Good usage of breakout rooms and real-time interpretive exercises
The engagement with the course was very high!
breakout rooms utilized to an appropriate degree; class presentations were engaging and useful
Hard to concentrate during a three-hour seminar on Zoom

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. Left with many changed perspectives on how I should think / engage with other thinkers in a creative way.
Phenomenal deep dive into one text. I would absolutely recommend this course especially to students with prior experiences in philosophy classes.

Absolutely. Professor North is incredibly knowledgeable and will help you make the most out of your reading of Zarathustra. Although I'm far from a Nietzschean, the insights and perspectives of this course have been influential to me.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. The text is engaging and the Professor North genuinely succeeds in preserving that engagement beyond the novelty of the first few seminars. A three-hour seminar is intimidating, but it frankly felt much shorter than even some of my 75 minute classes.
Yes! Take it for a fun, thought provoking and stimulating class with relatively easy grading.

Yes, you get to deeply scrutinize an incredible work of literature/philosophy over the course of the semester, although undertaking this much interpretive work and being inundated with so much Zarathustra can worsen one's mental health. Most of what you gain will probably be from reading the text and ruminating over it yourself.
Absolutely, this is a great dive into a great work.
Yes, if you already have a background in philosophy

I would highly recommend this course to any student interested in Nietzsche's philosophy, especially in his climactic work Thus Spoke Zarathustra. You engage with the text on a variety of levels, literarily and philosophically most often, and the insights gained through deep readings the text were astounding. The class also attracts some very intelligent students who can offer profound insights, and Professor North works to bring out the delicacies of Zarathustra's words. Took this as a philosophy major and I learned an incredible amount
Yes; the thinking developed in this course is useful for any field

Yes! This class will change the way you think about both philosophy and literature. Reading with Paul North is a paradigm shift. Reading Nietzsche is also a very exciting intellectual challenge - not easy to agree with, but disagreements always happen in interesting (and paper-inspiring) ways!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar
n/a
none
